revised_title: Sunshine Heat in London: A 24-Year Study from 1855 to 1874
tldr: This article presents a study of the heat of sunshine in London from 1855 to 1874, conducted by H. E. Roscoe and B. Stewart. They used Campbell's method to measure the heating effect of the sun and found that the heat of sunshine was greater during the second half of the year, with a remarkable uniformity in this pattern. The study also showed a correlation between solar heat and sunspot frequency, with more solar heat in years of maximum disturbance.
